results.title: It's elementary: talking about gay issues in school
results.creator_credit: Women's Educational Media, Helen S. Cohen and Debra Chasnoff
results.brief_description: It’s elementary provides parents and educators with information and advice on tackling gay and lesbian issues in schools. The documentary uses classroom footage and interviews with parents and teachers to examine what happens when homosexuality is discussed in the classroom. A wide range of teaching techniques and results are observed in six American schools of varying age levels, geographical locations, socio-economic and ethnic backgrounds. Issues such as homophobia, harassment, stereotypes, the law and family are discussed with students via brainstorming, storytelling, writing and guest speakers. The overriding relevancy of discussing homosexuality in schools and the appropriateness of the subject matter for various age groups is questioned and reinforced. The controversies, debates and opinions displayed in “It’s elementary” make fascinating viewing for a wide audience.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Women’s Educational Media, Helen S. Cohen and Debra Chasnoff

results.title: It's easy when you know how
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, Nicholas Cockram and Brian Bergin
results.brief_description: Children who have difficulty in learning may be lacking in the basic skills of the spoken or written language. They may appear to be dull, difficult, dyslexic or handicapped but step by step teaching may reveal that they have the ability to learn.

results.title: It's easy to criticize (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Panorama Productions, Peter Johnson and David E. Barrow
results.brief_description: Deals with the isolation many migrants feel when they are unable to communicate their difficulties and problems to Australians, especially those in authority. To help with these problems they have established their own clubs, where they can share their own language. Recently the New South Wales Government has established the Ethnic Affairs Commission to deal with migrant affairs and welfare.

results.title: It's different today
results.creator_credit: Motion Picture Associates, Film Australia, Peter Johnson and David E. Barrow
results.brief_description: This is a general recruiting film for the Royal Australina Navy. A young seaman waiting to join his ship is regaled by an old sailor with a discussion on ‘how things used to be when I was young’ intercut with action shots of navy manouvres and training exercises.

results.title: It's as easy as selling candy to a baby
results.brief_description: Examines the powerful influence of television in selling sugar-coated snack foods to children. One out of five commercials advertises food or beverage products. As well, medical experts document the health costs of these mesmerising messages to chilren, who as a result of sugar-rich diets, are suffering irreparable damage to their teeth. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: It's all up to you
results.brief_description: This short animated cartoon tells the story of two friends. One eats wisely and remains young and active. The other starts smoking, eats too much and becomes lazy and fat. His foolish way of living leads to a premature death.

results.title: It's all man-made
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information, Department of Environment, James Archibald and Robert Young
results.brief_description: Traces the impact of man’s industrial pursuits on the environment, focusing on the United Kingdom, and how industrialisation can work side-by-side with improving the natural landscape. Commentary by Ian Morrison.

results.title: It's about time
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and Danny Carter
results.brief_description: This film presents some extravagant or unusually designed historic time-pieces. Captures the ingenuity of horologists and craftsmen seen at work in a large factory producing clocks and watches on a mass production line. Commentary by Frank Hawkins.

results.title: It's a small world
results.creator_credit: British Information Services, Lewis Gilbert and Brian Smith
results.brief_description: Life in a typical nursery school in Britain, capturing their involvement in games, painting, modelling, climbing and acting and ending with a birthday tea party and a dip in a pool. Traditional gender roles can be observed as the girls cook in the kitchen, while the boys occupy themselves with building. A non-narrated film with musical accompaniment.
